text: Resting B and T lymphocytes contain high levels of <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA .

Stimulation of mouse B cells with anti-IgM or IgD antibodies , bacterial lipopolysaccharide , phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate plus ionomycin , or <extra_id_0> CD40 ligand <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> led to a five-fold to 35-fold decrease in <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA levels .

Similar downregulation of <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA was seen in human B cells stimulated with Staphylococcus aureus plus <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or anti-IgM antibodies and in human T lymphocytes stimulated with <extra_id_0> phytohemagglutinin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Although polyclonal activation of B cells in vitro invariably decreased <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> MRNA expression , activated B cells from human germinal centers expressed <extra_id_0> BCL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA at levels comparable to the levels in resting B cells .
